awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Social Cybersecurity: Applying Social Psychology to Improve Cybersecurity
awd_abstract_narration:
Past research investigating the human side of cybersecurity has treated people as isolated individuals rather than as social actors acting within a web of relationships and social influence. We are investigating how social influence can and does affect cybersecurity. More specifically, we are studying how people learn about new security behaviors from their social network, using both qualitative and quantitative methods.

We are also developing and evaluating novel techniques for leveraging social influences to improve people?s awareness and knowledge of cybersecurity, as well as motivation to act securely. These techniques make use of established principles from social psychology for influencing people, specifically similarity and social norms. We are applying these same ideas towards influencing people?s attitudes and behaviors towards cybersecurity.

Success in this work will open up a new dimension to cybersecurity and add to the toolbox for researchers and practitioners, in terms of applying known ideas from an established field in a new context to improve cybersecurity. Our work will also improve the community?s understanding of how people learn their cybersecurity behaviors (of which currently there is little literature), and will lead to a rigorous evaluation of how effective two different social mechanisms are in influencing people?s awareness, knowledge, and motivations towards acting more securely online.

por.por_cntn:
How can we use well-known techniques from social psychology to influence people in improving cybersecurity behavior and enhance security tool adoption?

Although there is a growing body of work on the human factors of cybersecurity, it has primarily focused on users as isolated individuals. Past work across several domains demonstrates the potential to encourage positive behavior change using social influences, for example in saving power or reusing towels in hotels. Work in social psychology has identified many kinds of social influences, including, for example, reciprocity, liking, authority, scarcity, and consistency.

In this project, a computer scientist and a social psychologist teamed up to conduct research to deepen our knowledge of how social influences can improve people’s awareness, knowledge, and motivation to be secure online. Below, we describe our major findings and impact.

In our first study, we conducted a series of interviews to understand why people recently did a security-related behavior, such as uninstalling an app, adding a PIN to their smartphone, or changing online privacy preferences. We found that a major portion of security behavior change was due to some social influence, and identified unique forms of social influences on security behavior for example pranking, social sensemaking, and observing others. We also found that conversations about security were most often driven by the desire to warn or protect others from immediate novel threats observed or experienced, or to gather information about solving an experienced problem. Furthermore, the observability of security feature usage was a key enabler of socially triggered behavior change—both in encouraging the spread of positive behaviors and in discouraging negative behaviors. 

In our second study, we conducted a large-scale experiment with Facebook, validating our qualitative interview findings (please see the attached image). We found that observability and social proof could be used to positively influence people’s willingness to adopt existing security features like two-factor authentication. By observability, we mean being able to see others gain benefit from using a security feature. By social proof, we mean showing people how many other people are using a security feature. This research paper won honorable mention for NSA’s Competition for Best Scientific Cybersecurity Paper in 2014, out of over 50 nominated papers.

In our third study, we conducted a post-hoc analysis of existing Facebook users, finding that number and diversity of friends were important factors in security feature adoption. That is, the more friends and the more diverse groups of friends that used a security feature, the more likely a person was to adopt a security feature. 

Overall, our work has led to new insights as to why people adopt security features and how to influence people's behaviors to improve cybersecurity. Our work also offers new tools for cybersecurity researchers and practitioners, in terms of understanding how to incorporate social influences into design. Lastly, our work has opened up cybersecurity to more researchers, beyond just computer science, showing how behavioral scientists (in particular psychologists) can help improve the state of the art.

 

The goal of the proposed work is to deepen our knowledge of how social influences can improve people’s security
